dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And Berkshire Hathaway moved up five spots since the previous year, even though they had a major stock split in late 2018.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA

HostB: Right, and they actually fell behind Apple and Berkshire Hathaway, which is pretty surprising given how dominant banks usually are globally.
HostA: Yeah, and speaking of Apple, they ranked second on the U.S. list in 2019, but get this—they were also the second least profitable public company in the world.
HostB: Wait, really? Even though they pulled in nearly thirty billion dollars last year? That just shows how massive some of these other companies must be.
HostA: Exactly. And Apple still had a market cap of about five hundred billion dollars at that time, which is just staggering.
HostB: Meanwhile, Citigroup actually saw rising profits, thanks in large part to those tax cuts set in motion back in 2018.
HostA: Yeah, but then they plunged all the way down to number twenty-nine on the extended list because of overseas asset losses. Talk about a roller coaster.
HostB: And Berkshire Hathaway moved up five spots since the previous year, even though they had a major stock split in late 2018.
HostA: It’s interesting how the U.S. top fifty are worth over two trillion combined, but only ten of them are major banks.
HostB: Right, whereas the global list is way more bank-heavy. The U.S. seems a lot more diversified with tech and retail giants like Amazon and Walmart in the mix too.
HostA: And Intel and Alphabet are up there at eight and nine—tech is clearly dominating the American corporate landscape.
HostB: But then 2019 was such a volatile year for stocks overall, especially with all that trade war tension with China.
HostA: For sure. Investors are probably wondering if that kind of uncertainty is just gonna be the new normal moving forward.
